s1: This course is the first of three core computer science courses on programming.
s2: This is an advanced undergraduate course that covers advanced topics in Artificial Intelligence. Topics vary from one offering to the next and are likely to be drawn from the following list: planning, scheduling, games, search, reasoning (constraint-based, model-based, spatial, temporal), knowledge representation, decision-making under uncertainty, reinforcement learning, agents, foundations.

s1: It introduces students to the field of computer science as a discipline for solving problems through computation and provides the foundation for more advanced courses on programming and software development.

s1: Data structures and algorithms, the key concepts at the core of computer science, receive their first treatment in this course. The course addresses both functional and imperative programming paradigms.

s1: Students learn the organization of programming languages using types, how programs are evaluated (reduction), functional composition, recursive functions, algebraic data types, pattern matching, parametric polymorphism, higher-order functions.
s2: This is an advanced undergraduate course that covers advanced topics in Artificial Intelligence.
